Vol. III.

Fortnightly

THE SALVATION OF THE GRADUATE
STUDENT.

The average graduate student himself would
probably be the last to admit that he needed
salvation—that is, at least, any earthly kind.
He is, of course, as a rule, passably well endowed with religious instincts, and therefore
quite willing to confess that he is "a miserable
sinner;" but that is far from saying that the
rest of mankind is not also thus, and even
more so. Quite the contrary! He has—
probably all his life, certainly through the
term of his college and university existence—
worked harder and revelled less than the most
of his companions. Even now he is mortifying his flesh for the good of his higher nature
by incessant studying, both night and day.
How absurd, then, that anyone should project
the leavening of his stern rectitude with a little more of human frailty, and call that—his
salvation. And yet he needs just this. He
may have withstood the temptations of drinking, gambling, loafing, and all the rest. He
must still be saved from himself; that is, from
the conditions which at present surround him.
The truth of this will become evident on a
little reflection. When a man enters upon
some special graduate work, he finds that his
department gives him much more of advantages than of time in which to avail himself
of them. These advantages have, perhaps,
cost him some sacrifice to obtain, while to enjoy them he has only this one opportunity.
So he feels—and justly—the need of compressing all outside demands on his time into
the smallest bounds possible, that he may
give the utmost of it to his specialty.
But though this cramming of his time is
necessary, there is yet attendant on it a twofold danger. In the first place, his nervous
system is bound to suffer from the unremitting tax upon it; the importance of this point,
anyone who reads the article in Outing of Oc-

No

tober 1st on Relaxation is sure to recognize.
And, in the second place, he is liable to undergo that of the sympathies, involved in pure
specialization, and fatal to him if he intends
to take a place, and a worthy one, in life. For
how can a teacher, for instance, get the best
results from the men under him, unless he is
in actual comprehending sympathy with the
nature of each of them? And how can he be
in such sympathy, when he has renounced the
world about him for a narrow double ego—
himself and his special line of study? I do
not say that this has actually happened to
many, or even any, of our graduates; but I
believe it to be a danger which threatens all.
To counteract this dangerous tendency,
there are at present no means at his hand.
None, at least, within the University. He
may go into society, should he possess or be
able to form an outside circle of friends.
Should he do so, it is bound to prove a serious
distraction and handicap to his work. But
of the companionship most likely to be of
value to himself—the men of other departments of his own University, whose life and
purposes lie along the same lines as his
own, yet who have, from the difference of
their work, a certain refreshing difference
of ideas—of this he has none. He may
meet them at boarding-house or fraternity;
he may have known them before he came
here. But as far as his university existence
goes, there is no reason whatever why he
should ever come to know them. There is,
indeed, a -Graduate Students' Association"
whose name would imply some commingling
of its members. But in the first place, only
a small proportion of the graduates belong to
the Association. And those who do need
never see each other, except at the semi-occasional cake and lemonade functions—mournful affairs, whose stiff conversation is not at
all calculated to compensate a man for giving

THE NEWS-LETTER.
THE COLLEGE CONGRESS.

Graded instruction in public speaking, continuing through the three years of residence,
is now an established feature of the Hopkins
collegiate course. The general acceptance of
the work done last year, the favorable appearance of the contestants in public debate, and
evident appreciation on the part of the men,
has Sled to an increase of hours for the course
and a broadening of its scope. The instruction will be given, as last year, by Dr. Guy
Carleton Lee.
The Senior and Junior classes will meet an
hour weekly, with the exception of the winter
term, when the Seniors will meet every other
week only. The Senior class, as formerly,
will be organized as a Senate; the Juniors as
a House of Representatives. This College
Congress, however, will convene only on alternate weeks; every second week will'be devoted to class instruction in Parliamentary
Law and Practice, extemporaneous speaking
and debate. In the Senior class no text book
will be employed other than a syllabus prepared by Dr. Lee. As a work of reference, "Roberts's Parliamentary Syllabus" and
"Rules of Order" will be used by the Junior
class.
In addition to the regular weekly meetings,
conferences will be arranged for the upper
classmen, for the study of methods of collecting and sifting evidence, drawing briefs and
preparation for debate.
A happy innovation in the College Congress will be the arrangement in a related series of the subjects for debate. Each topic will
be some phase of the great question of Territorial Expansion now so widely agitated. The
subjects will be so planned that there will be
no interlocking of arguments, and the entire
series will furnish a practical survey of Politics in the Nineteenth Century. The public
and inter-class debate in the spring will be
based on the subject matter of the winter's
studies. i. his thorough preparation will forcefully and brilliantly arm the contestants.
More time this year will be given to open

3

debate, as but two speakers on each side will
regularly be assigned.
The Freshmen class is divided into sections
for the study of Description, Narration, Exposition and Argument, as used in speaking.
No text is available for the course, because of
its practical nature, so a syllabus prepared
by Dr. Lee, issued week by week, will be used.
The class will participate in the contest in
public speaking next spring.

Dere ez a soun' ob Summah in de air;
Sweet music am wafted on de breeze:
Hyeah de crickets chirpin' in de low grass,
While de frogs air trillin' in de trees.
Han' en han' we wu walkin' thoo de meddah,
Wif de moonbeams spawklin' on huh ha'ar,
'Twell my hea't wu' a'trippin' lak a hammah,
Ez I gaze on my 'Liza Ann so fair.
It seem lak de Heabens gone done open,
Wif de angels ahoy' rin all aroun';
0 true-love, de Glory-Lan' wu' breakin'I
Gold an' silba lay scattud o' de groun'.
We ling'ud by de gate neah de yellums;
I drew clos'a, stan'in' by huh side,
Huh haid res'in' sof'ly on my should'a—
I pine den to tek huh fo' my bride.
Porn my hea't came de words dat I whisp'ud,
Sof' en low, whisp'ud only fo' huh ears;
On huh cheek a di'mun' seem to glis'en;—
Wif huh han' she breshed away de tears.
Den I know dat 'Liza Ann, my true-love,
Huh hea't en han' hed given unt'a me;
Could I ask fo' any futh'a promise?—
My bride, flex' come Chrismus, huh will be.
Hi! Dere's a soun' of Summah in de air;
Sweet music am wafted on de breeze;
Hyeah de crickets chirpin' in de low grass,
While de frogs air trillin' in de trees.
W. P. SHRINER.

Subscriptions and business communications should be sent

of Johns Hopkins Hospital.

To those who were members of the University last year THE NEWS-LETTER needs no introduction and makes no apologies for its existence. For the new students it has a word
of greeting. We would call their attention to
the fact that this is the only publication of its
kind at the University. It is not a literary
magazine, nor a comic journal, but primarily
a newspaper. It is distinctly an amateur effort, and the editors gain nothing but experience. The fact that we try to represent so
many diverse elements makes the problem difficult. It also makes it right for us to expect
the undivided allegiance of the students. We
hope to have as subscribers this year, practically all the undergraduates and very many
graduate students.
Last spring at Maryland Oval, Hopkins
won with the greatest case the championship
of the Maryland Intercollegiate Association.
A few weeks ago, with scarcely greater difficulty, we carried off the championship in the
gatnes of the Maryland Athletic Union. These
associations include practically all the track
and field teams in the State, and these victories give Hopkins a clear title to athletic supremacy in her own neighborhood. This supremacy we can easily maintain, and it be-

hooves us, while keeping up our present standard, to look beyond our borders for more
worthy opponents. Our athletes should begin
at once to think about the American Intercollegiate games for next year. In this connection, the most encouraging sign of the times is
the appointment of Mr. Mackdermott to have
full charge of the outdoor sports of the University. Mr. Mackdermott's efficiency as a
coach,and his interest in Hopkins affairs, have
been abundantly proved, and the agreement
between the Athletic Association and the trustees which resulted in his appointment was a
most happy one.
Although our representatives in the volunteer army in the late war with Spain did not
reach the scene of actual conflict, and we have
no wounded heroes to idolize, nevertheless the
war has touched us on many sides, and we may
claim some share at least in its glory. Besides
those who were actually mustered into the service of the government with the Maryland National Guard, we must remember the others
in the cavalry and artillery who were ready
and anxious to go. Nurses from the Medical
School were active in the work of the Red
Cross. Some of our electricians were engaged
in harbor defense at Baltimore. A member
of the University faculty is now absent on
duty, and our president was offered a place on
the commission to inquire into the affairs of
the war department.
Events since the mass-meeting last term
have proved the truth of President Gilman's
assertion that the government did not need us,
and have fully justified Prof. Adams' advice
about going off at half cock. Our military
company began bravely, and diminished in
rapid progression until there were few left to
disband. Fortunately the suggestion of some
over-zealous ones, that military training be
made a prominent feature here, died with
the company. Such things are all right in
time of war, but at other times we can wisely
leave them to "prep" schools, to whom they
belong.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
BOOK NOTES.

There is no rest for the weary librarian.
He has steadfastly to stick to his books. All
the libraries have been thoroughly overhauled
during the summer, and there were many valuable accessions to the Hopkins' collections.
Dr. Keidel devoted the greater part of the
summer to cataloguing and rearranging the
books of the department of Romance Languages.
Professor Cleveland Abbe's rich library on
Meteorology has come to Hopkins. The collection is regarded as one of the most complete on the subject in this country, with the
exception, perhaps, of that at the Weather
Bureau in Washington. The Abbe Library
numbers about fifteen hundred volumes, and
will be in the charge of Mr. Fassig, late of the
Washington Bureau Library, now connected
with the Weather Service here and aS a lecturer in the University.
A glance over the exhibit of the New Book
Department brings to light de Tocqueville's
"Democracy in America," with an introduction by President Gilman; "The State," by
Woodrow Wilson, in a revised edition; and
the second volume of "The Historical Development of Modern Europe," by 'Charles M.
Andrews (Ph. D.'88), now associate professor
at Bryn Mawr. Dr. Andrews' scholarly work
is attracting wide attention. The Century
Co., by the way, will shortly issue a volume of
President Gilman's addresses on University
Problems.
"Irrigation in Utah," published by C. H.
Brough (Ph. D.'98), in the Hopkins series of
- Historical Studies, has had an extensive sale
in the West. Dr. Brough is looking to a second edition.
Several of the recent publications on the
New Book table are eminently noteworthy.
The first of four volumes of "Scientific Memories of Huxley," edited by Professors Foster
and Lankester; twenty-two masterly plates
accompany the text. "A Constitutional History of the American People, 1776-1850," by
Francis Newton Thorpe, in two volumes,

5

conies from the Harper's press, and in point
ot typography, paper, printing and binding, is
representative of the highest order of practical
book-making, a work which gives delight even
in the handling.
PERSONALS.

Ernest M. Jenkins and Vincent Renouf
were among the Hopkins men at Narragansett Pier this summer.
John P. Hill, 'oo, was associated with the
Coast and Geodetic Survey on the resurvey of
Chester river, employed on hydrographic
work.
Marion Jungbluth, Duncan K. Brent, Frederick W. and R. Marsden Smith, Albert Keidel and George M. Clarke were among the foreign tourists.
Wilson L. Smith, 'oo, camped on the Susquehanna in the early summer, and later made
a tour of the coast resorts.
Captain Robinson, '99, of the 'Varsity football team, and Louis W. Haskell, '99, spent a
large part of the summer in southern waters
off the coast of Georgia.
Alex. V. Schermerhorn, 'oo, spent the summer abroad, visiting Holland, England and
Wales.
Ferd. C. Fisher, '99, divided his vacation
between the mountains and seashore, visiting
Monterey and Atlantic City.
Harry Grimes, '99, and George W. Knapp,
'99, took an extended trip North. They travelled in Canada, and returned by way of Lake
George and the Hudson river. Saratoga,
Newport, Narragansett and other points of
interest were included in their itinerary.
James L. A. Burrell,'oo, was connected with
the Maryland State Geological Survey, and
had some rough and tumble experiences in the
mountain country of Western Maryland. During the heat of the war the corps was nearly
famished for news, as an occasional paper
only strayed into camp.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
ATHLE,TICS.
ANOTHER CHAMPIONSHIP.

At the first annual track and field games of
the Maryland Athletic Union, held at Maryland Oval, September 24, Hopkins athletes
began their work for this season by winning
another championship. The most important
prize was "The News Cup," which was offered
to the club scoring the highest number of
points, and which will become the permanent
property of the club first winning three championships (not necessarily in succession).
This cup is now on exhibition with other Hopkins prizes in the Trophy Room.
The men composing our team deserve the
more credit in view of the fact that the games
were held before the beginning of our school
year, when a number of our men were out of
town.
Nevertheless enough men were collected to
represent us in most events, and to score for
us twice as many points as our nearest competitor.
The day was perfect, except that a strong
wind was blowing up the finish. In consequence of a hard rain on the previous day the
track was in poor condition. However, records went smashing, and new State championships were established. In the first event, the
mo-yard dash, Hopkins won first and second.
Knapp ran in his usual form, and won first in
Jo 3-5 seconds, breaking the previous State
record of 10 4-5. Talty was a close second.
In the 220 Knapp continued his good work,
winning first in 24 seconds, and establishing
another State record. The former record was
24 3-5. C. T. Clark made second place in the
88o-yard run, crossing the tape close behind
C. W. Hammill, of the Y. M. C. A. In the
mile run, unfortunately Hopkins did not get
a place. We have, however, every reason to
be proud of the work of R. T. Abercrombie,
who ran until he dropped. Had he been in his
usual condition he would doubtless have won
a place. While nearly everything was going

our way on the track, it was much the same
in the field. In the running high jump Garrett won third and Weedon fourth. In the
other events in which Garrett was entered he
won first, making new State records for the
running hop, step and jump and 16-111 hammer throw. In the former his distance was 42
feet 10 inches, and he threw the hammer 107
feet 8 1-2 inches. In putting the 16-lb. shot
he covered 37 feet 7 1-2 inches. H. S. Whitman won third, with 32 feet 4 1-2 inches, and
T. Fitzgerald fourth, 27 feet 5 1-2 inches. Garrett's running broad jump was 21 feet 2 inches,
and he threw the discus 95 feet 9 inches. In
the latter event Fitzgerald was second, with
89 feet 2 inches, and Whitman third, 86 feet
2 inches.
W. Weedon won second place in the running hop, step and jump, with 41 feet 10 1-4
inches.
Thomas Fitzgerald ran a beautiful race in
the 440-yard run, winning first in 56 3-5 seconds. Morfit Mullen finished close up, winning third. In the bicycle races, which were
considerably mixed up and run on a track ill
suited to the purpose, we had no representatives.
The last and most interesting event was the
one-mile relay, which Hopkins won hands
down, in 3 minutes 46 3-5 seconds.
The team was composed of S. P. Smith, Geo.
W. Knapp, Jr., J. M. Mullen and T. Fitzgerald, Jr. Smith, the new man on the team, ran
well, leading from the start. The other men
easily increased the lead. Much of the credit
of our easy victory is due to the coaching of
Mr. Wm. M. Mackdermott.
The final standing of the clubs by points is
as follows:

Maryland Athletic Club

Baltimore Athletic Club

THE NEWS-LETTER.
UNIVERSITY CHAT.

Through the summer vacation months the
faculty was widely scattered in travel, at home
and abroad, or in quiet recreation in the mountains or along the coast.
President Gilman was at North-east Harbor, Maine.
Dean Griffin and family spent the season at
Lake Placid, the Adirondacks.
Dr. Ames travelled on the Continent and in
England.
Dr. Kirby Smith was among the Hopkinsians at the White Sulphur Springs, Virginia.
Of the Medical Faculty, Dr. Oster was in
,Europe; Dr. Halsted spent the summer in the
mountains of North Carolina.
Prof. Ira Remsen was in Vermont and at
Deer Isle, Maine.
Prof. Adams spent the vacation months in
literary work at Amherst.
Dr. Spieker travelled through the West, remaining some weeks in Nevada.
Dr. Thomas S. Baker devoted several
months to study and travel in Germany.
Dr. and Mrs. Vincent sought the seclusion
of a quiet little town in Ohio, six miles from a
railroad, where they were free to carry on their
literary work.
Dr. E. E. Reed, of the Chemical Department, has been called to the professorship of
chemistry and physics at the Charlestown
University, S. C.
President Gilman was in New York last
week for the meeting of the Peabody Educational Fund. He was elected a member of
the Committee on Finance.
The Adirondacks were quite popular with
Hopkins men this summer. E. S. Bruce and
John W. Griffin spent the season there. A
number of Hopkinsians canoed in Maine waters. Conway S. Hodges, Howard Post,
Charles M. Remsen and Edward L'Engle were
among those who either pitched their tents at
the picturesque Lake Moosehead or shot the
rapids that abound in Maine streams.

Registrar Ball gives out the approximate
enrollment of students to date of October 5 as:
Graduates, 206; medical, 202; undergraduates, 190. The total, 598, is somewhat in
excess of the enrollment of last year.
The entering class numbers 69, 6o candidates for the degree of A. B., and 9 special
students. Sixty-three students are entered
in the first year class of the Medical School.
The prospects for the usual up-to-date
Banjo, Mandolin and Glee Clubs, this year,
are very bright. The first trials have been
held and a number of new faces will appear
in the make-up of the clubs. Tours are
planned for both the Christmas and Easter vacations, under the management of Joshua Levering, Jr.,'99. Marion K. Jungbluth,'99, will
this year lead the Glee Club. As last year, the
Mandolin and Banjo Clubs will be led by Girvin Peters.
At the reception tendered the incoming students by the Y. M. C. A., Mr. Eugene Levering, representing the Board of Trustees, spoke
with great feeling of the late Dr. James Carey
Thomas, who for so many years had identified
himself with the Association's work in the University.
Professor Adams will conduct, as a department of the Association's work, a study of the
Apostolic Church and the Growth of Modern
Missions, Saturday mornings at half-past nine.
Professor Adams' course last year on the Lif:
of Christ was largely attended by graduates
and undergraduates, and this year's studies
promise to be equally well attended.
At the conclusion of Prof. Adams's lecture,
Dr. Jeffrey R. Brackett will conduct a half
hour's conference on Applied Sociology, from
o to 10.30 every Saturday.
Dr. Brackett
aims to interest university men in practical
social work, and in the social problems of the
city. The 'Varsity Y. M. C. A. is at present
largely interested in the Lawrence House, a
social settlement work begun in the Winans'
tenements of Southwest Baltimore, in 1893,
by the late Rev. Edward A. Lawrence.

THE SALVATION OF THE GRADUATE
STUDENT.

The average graduate student himself would
probably be the last to admit that he needed
salvation—that is, at least, any earthly kind.
He is, of course, as a rule, passably well endowed with religious instincts, and therefore
quite willing to confess that he is "a miserable
sinner;" but that is far from saying that the
rest of mankind is not also thus, and even
more so. Quite the contrary! He has—
probably all his life, certainly through the
term of his college and university existence—
worked harder and revelled less than the most
of his companions. Even now he is mortifying his flesh for the good of his higher nature
by incessant studying, both night and day.
How absurd, then, that anyone should project
the leavening of his stern rectitude with a little more of human frailty, and call that—his
salvation. And yet he needs just this. He
may have withstood the temptations of drinking, gambling, loafing, and all the rest. He
must still be saved from himself; that is, from
the conditions which at present surround him.
The truth of this will become evident on a
little reflection. When a man enters upon
some special graduate work, he finds that his
department gives him much more of advantages than of time in which to avail himself
of them. These advantages have, perhaps,
cost him some sacrifice to obtain, while to enjoy them he has only this one opportunity.
So he feels—and justly—the need of compressing all outside demands on his time into
the smallest bounds possible, that he may
give the utmost of it to his specialty.
But though this cramming of his time is
necessary, there is yet attendant on it a twofold danger. In the first place, his nervous
system is bound to suffer from the unremitting tax upon it; the importance of this point,
anyone who reads the article in Outing of Oc-

No

tober 1st on Relaxation is sure to recognize.
And, in the second place, he is liable to undergo that of the sympathies, involved in pure
specialization, and fatal to him if he intends
to take a place, and a worthy one, in life. For
how can a teacher, for instance, get the best
results from the men under him, unless he is
in actual comprehending sympathy with the
nature of each of them? And how can he be
in such sympathy, when he has renounced the
world about him for a narrow double ego—
himself and his special line of study? I do
not say that this has actually happened to
many, or even any, of our graduates; but I
believe it to be a danger which threatens all.
To counteract this dangerous tendency,
there are at present no means at his hand.
None, at least, within the University. He
may go into society, should he possess or be
able to form an outside circle of friends.
Should he do so, it is bound to prove a serious
distraction and handicap to his work. But
of the companionship most likely to be of
value to himself—the men of other departments of his own University, whose life and
purposes lie along the same lines as his
own, yet who have, from the difference of
their work, a certain refreshing difference
of ideas—of this he has none. He may
meet them at boarding-house or fraternity;
he may have known them before he came
here. But as far as his university existence
goes, there is no reason whatever why he
should ever come to know them. There is,
indeed, a -Graduate Students' Association"
whose name would imply some commingling
of its members. But in the first place, only
a small proportion of the graduates belong to
the Association. And those who do need
never see each other, except at the semi-occasional cake and lemonade functions—mournful affairs, whose stiff conversation is not at
all calculated to compensate a man for giving

THE NEWS-LETTER.
THE COLLEGE CONGRESS.

Graded instruction in public speaking, continuing through the three years of residence,
is now an established feature of the Hopkins
collegiate course. The general acceptance of
the work done last year, the favorable appearance of the contestants in public debate, and
evident appreciation on the part of the men,
has Sled to an increase of hours for the course
and a broadening of its scope. The instruction will be given, as last year, by Dr. Guy
Carleton Lee.
The Senior and Junior classes will meet an
hour weekly, with the exception of the winter
term, when the Seniors will meet every other
week only. The Senior class, as formerly,
will be organized as a Senate; the Juniors as
a House of Representatives. This College
Congress, however, will convene only on alternate weeks; every second week will'be devoted to class instruction in Parliamentary
Law and Practice, extemporaneous speaking
and debate. In the Senior class no text book
will be employed other than a syllabus prepared by Dr. Lee. As a work of reference, "Roberts's Parliamentary Syllabus" and
"Rules of Order" will be used by the Junior
class.
In addition to the regular weekly meetings,
conferences will be arranged for the upper
classmen, for the study of methods of collecting and sifting evidence, drawing briefs and
preparation for debate.
A happy innovation in the College Congress will be the arrangement in a related series of the subjects for debate. Each topic will
be some phase of the great question of Territorial Expansion now so widely agitated. The
subjects will be so planned that there will be
no interlocking of arguments, and the entire
series will furnish a practical survey of Politics in the Nineteenth Century. The public
and inter-class debate in the spring will be
based on the subject matter of the winter's
studies. i. his thorough preparation will forcefully and brilliantly arm the contestants.
More time this year will be given to open

3

debate, as but two speakers on each side will
regularly be assigned.
The Freshmen class is divided into sections
for the study of Description, Narration, Exposition and Argument, as used in speaking.
No text is available for the course, because of
its practical nature, so a syllabus prepared
by Dr. Lee, issued week by week, will be used.
The class will participate in the contest in
public speaking next spring.

Dere ez a soun' ob Summah in de air;
Sweet music am wafted on de breeze:
Hyeah de crickets chirpin' in de low grass,
While de frogs air trillin' in de trees.
Han' en han' we wu walkin' thoo de meddah,
Wif de moonbeams spawklin' on huh ha'ar,
'Twell my hea't wu' a'trippin' lak a hammah,
Ez I gaze on my 'Liza Ann so fair.
It seem lak de Heabens gone done open,
Wif de angels ahoy' rin all aroun';
0 true-love, de Glory-Lan' wu' breakin'I
Gold an' silba lay scattud o' de groun'.
We ling'ud by de gate neah de yellums;
I drew clos'a, stan'in' by huh side,
Huh haid res'in' sof'ly on my should'a—
I pine den to tek huh fo' my bride.
Porn my hea't came de words dat I whisp'ud,
Sof' en low, whisp'ud only fo' huh ears;
On huh cheek a di'mun' seem to glis'en;—
Wif huh han' she breshed away de tears.
Den I know dat 'Liza Ann, my true-love,
Huh hea't en han' hed given unt'a me;
Could I ask fo' any futh'a promise?—
My bride, flex' come Chrismus, huh will be.
Hi! Dere's a soun' of Summah in de air;
Sweet music am wafted on de breeze;
Hyeah de crickets chirpin' in de low grass,
While de frogs air trillin' in de trees.
W. P. SHRINER.

To those who were members of the University last year THE NEWS-LETTER needs no introduction and makes no apologies for its existence. For the new students it has a word
of greeting. We would call their attention to
the fact that this is the only publication of its
kind at the University. It is not a literary
magazine, nor a comic journal, but primarily
a newspaper. It is distinctly an amateur effort, and the editors gain nothing but experience. The fact that we try to represent so
many diverse elements makes the problem difficult. It also makes it right for us to expect
the undivided allegiance of the students. We
hope to have as subscribers this year, practically all the undergraduates and very many
graduate students.
Last spring at Maryland Oval, Hopkins
won with the greatest case the championship
of the Maryland Intercollegiate Association.
A few weeks ago, with scarcely greater difficulty, we carried off the championship in the
gatnes of the Maryland Athletic Union. These
associations include practically all the track
and field teams in the State, and these victories give Hopkins a clear title to athletic supremacy in her own neighborhood. This supremacy we can easily maintain, and it be-

hooves us, while keeping up our present standard, to look beyond our borders for more
worthy opponents. Our athletes should begin
at once to think about the American Intercollegiate games for next year. In this connection, the most encouraging sign of the times is
the appointment of Mr. Mackdermott to have
full charge of the outdoor sports of the University. Mr. Mackdermott's efficiency as a
coach,and his interest in Hopkins affairs, have
been abundantly proved, and the agreement
between the Athletic Association and the trustees which resulted in his appointment was a
most happy one.
Although our representatives in the volunteer army in the late war with Spain did not
reach the scene of actual conflict, and we have
no wounded heroes to idolize, nevertheless the
war has touched us on many sides, and we may
claim some share at least in its glory. Besides
those who were actually mustered into the service of the government with the Maryland National Guard, we must remember the others
in the cavalry and artillery who were ready
and anxious to go. Nurses from the Medical
School were active in the work of the Red
Cross. Some of our electricians were engaged
in harbor defense at Baltimore. A member
of the University faculty is now absent on
duty, and our president was offered a place on
the commission to inquire into the affairs of
the war department.
Events since the mass-meeting last term
have proved the truth of President Gilman's
assertion that the government did not need us,
and have fully justified Prof. Adams' advice
about going off at half cock. Our military
company began bravely, and diminished in
rapid progression until there were few left to
disband. Fortunately the suggestion of some
over-zealous ones, that military training be
made a prominent feature here, died with
the company. Such things are all right in
time of war, but at other times we can wisely
leave them to "prep" schools, to whom they
belong.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
BOOK NOTES.

There is no rest for the weary librarian.
He has steadfastly to stick to his books. All
the libraries have been thoroughly overhauled
during the summer, and there were many valuable accessions to the Hopkins' collections.
Dr. Keidel devoted the greater part of the
summer to cataloguing and rearranging the
books of the department of Romance Languages.
Professor Cleveland Abbe's rich library on
Meteorology has come to Hopkins. The collection is regarded as one of the most complete on the subject in this country, with the
exception, perhaps, of that at the Weather
Bureau in Washington. The Abbe Library
numbers about fifteen hundred volumes, and
will be in the charge of Mr. Fassig, late of the
Washington Bureau Library, now connected
with the Weather Service here and aS a lecturer in the University.
A glance over the exhibit of the New Book
Department brings to light de Tocqueville's
"Democracy in America," with an introduction by President Gilman; "The State," by
Woodrow Wilson, in a revised edition; and
the second volume of "The Historical Development of Modern Europe," by 'Charles M.
Andrews (Ph. D.'88), now associate professor
at Bryn Mawr. Dr. Andrews' scholarly work
is attracting wide attention. The Century
Co., by the way, will shortly issue a volume of
President Gilman's addresses on University
Problems.
"Irrigation in Utah," published by C. H.
Brough (Ph. D.'98), in the Hopkins series of
- Historical Studies, has had an extensive sale
in the West. Dr. Brough is looking to a second edition.
Several of the recent publications on the
New Book table are eminently noteworthy.
The first of four volumes of "Scientific Memories of Huxley," edited by Professors Foster
and Lankester; twenty-two masterly plates
accompany the text. "A Constitutional History of the American People, 1776-1850," by
Francis Newton Thorpe, in two volumes,

5

conies from the Harper's press, and in point
ot typography, paper, printing and binding, is
representative of the highest order of practical
book-making, a work which gives delight even
in the handling.
PERSONALS.

Ernest M. Jenkins and Vincent Renouf
were among the Hopkins men at Narragansett Pier this summer.
John P. Hill, 'oo, was associated with the
Coast and Geodetic Survey on the resurvey of
Chester river, employed on hydrographic
work.
Marion Jungbluth, Duncan K. Brent, Frederick W. and R. Marsden Smith, Albert Keidel and George M. Clarke were among the foreign tourists.
Wilson L. Smith, 'oo, camped on the Susquehanna in the early summer, and later made
a tour of the coast resorts.
Captain Robinson, '99, of the 'Varsity football team, and Louis W. Haskell, '99, spent a
large part of the summer in southern waters
off the coast of Georgia.
Alex. V. Schermerhorn, 'oo, spent the summer abroad, visiting Holland, England and
Wales.
Ferd. C. Fisher, '99, divided his vacation
between the mountains and seashore, visiting
Monterey and Atlantic City.
Harry Grimes, '99, and George W. Knapp,
'99, took an extended trip North. They travelled in Canada, and returned by way of Lake
George and the Hudson river. Saratoga,
Newport, Narragansett and other points of
interest were included in their itinerary.
James L. A. Burrell,'oo, was connected with
the Maryland State Geological Survey, and
had some rough and tumble experiences in the
mountain country of Western Maryland. During the heat of the war the corps was nearly
famished for news, as an occasional paper
only strayed into camp.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
ATHLE,TICS.
ANOTHER CHAMPIONSHIP.

At the first annual track and field games of
the Maryland Athletic Union, held at Maryland Oval, September 24, Hopkins athletes
began their work for this season by winning
another championship. The most important
prize was "The News Cup," which was offered
to the club scoring the highest number of
points, and which will become the permanent
property of the club first winning three championships (not necessarily in succession).
This cup is now on exhibition with other Hopkins prizes in the Trophy Room.
The men composing our team deserve the
more credit in view of the fact that the games
were held before the beginning of our school
year, when a number of our men were out of
town.
Nevertheless enough men were collected to
represent us in most events, and to score for
us twice as many points as our nearest competitor.
The day was perfect, except that a strong
wind was blowing up the finish. In consequence of a hard rain on the previous day the
track was in poor condition. However, records went smashing, and new State championships were established. In the first event, the
mo-yard dash, Hopkins won first and second.
Knapp ran in his usual form, and won first in
Jo 3-5 seconds, breaking the previous State
record of 10 4-5. Talty was a close second.
In the 220 Knapp continued his good work,
winning first in 24 seconds, and establishing
another State record. The former record was
24 3-5. C. T. Clark made second place in the
88o-yard run, crossing the tape close behind
C. W. Hammill, of the Y. M. C. A. In the
mile run, unfortunately Hopkins did not get
a place. We have, however, every reason to
be proud of the work of R. T. Abercrombie,
who ran until he dropped. Had he been in his
usual condition he would doubtless have won
a place. While nearly everything was going

our way on the track, it was much the same
in the field. In the running high jump Garrett won third and Weedon fourth. In the
other events in which Garrett was entered he
won first, making new State records for the
running hop, step and jump and 16-111 hammer throw. In the former his distance was 42
feet 10 inches, and he threw the hammer 107
feet 8 1-2 inches. In putting the 16-lb. shot
he covered 37 feet 7 1-2 inches. H. S. Whitman won third, with 32 feet 4 1-2 inches, and
T. Fitzgerald fourth, 27 feet 5 1-2 inches. Garrett's running broad jump was 21 feet 2 inches,
and he threw the discus 95 feet 9 inches. In
the latter event Fitzgerald was second, with
89 feet 2 inches, and Whitman third, 86 feet
2 inches.
W. Weedon won second place in the running hop, step and jump, with 41 feet 10 1-4
inches.
Thomas Fitzgerald ran a beautiful race in
the 440-yard run, winning first in 56 3-5 seconds. Morfit Mullen finished close up, winning third. In the bicycle races, which were
considerably mixed up and run on a track ill
suited to the purpose, we had no representatives.
The last and most interesting event was the
one-mile relay, which Hopkins won hands
down, in 3 minutes 46 3-5 seconds.
The team was composed of S. P. Smith, Geo.
W. Knapp, Jr., J. M. Mullen and T. Fitzgerald, Jr. Smith, the new man on the team, ran
well, leading from the start. The other men
easily increased the lead. Much of the credit
of our easy victory is due to the coaching of
Mr. Wm. M. Mackdermott.
The final standing of the clubs by points is
as follows:
Johns Hopkins
Maryland Athletic Club
Y. M. C. A.
Baltimore Athletic Club
St. Leo's Gymnasium
Druid Athletic Club
Guilford Athletic Club

THE NEWS-LETTER.
UNIVERSITY CHAT.

Through the summer vacation months the
faculty was widely scattered in travel, at home
and abroad, or in quiet recreation in the mountains or along the coast.
President Gilman was at North-east Harbor, Maine.
Dean Griffin and family spent the season at
Lake Placid, the Adirondacks.
Dr. Ames travelled on the Continent and in
England.
Dr. Kirby Smith was among the Hopkinsians at the White Sulphur Springs, Virginia.
Of the Medical Faculty, Dr. Oster was in
,Europe; Dr. Halsted spent the summer in the
mountains of North Carolina.
Prof. Ira Remsen was in Vermont and at
Deer Isle, Maine.
Prof. Adams spent the vacation months in
literary work at Amherst.
Dr. Spieker travelled through the West, remaining some weeks in Nevada.
Dr. Thomas S. Baker devoted several
months to study and travel in Germany.
Dr. and Mrs. Vincent sought the seclusion
of a quiet little town in Ohio, six miles from a
railroad, where they were free to carry on their
literary work.
Dr. E. E. Reed, of the Chemical Department, has been called to the professorship of
chemistry and physics at the Charlestown
University, S. C.
President Gilman was in New York last
week for the meeting of the Peabody Educational Fund. He was elected a member of
the Committee on Finance.
The Adirondacks were quite popular with
Hopkins men this summer. E. S. Bruce and
John W. Griffin spent the season there. A
number of Hopkinsians canoed in Maine waters. Conway S. Hodges, Howard Post,
Charles M. Remsen and Edward L'Engle were
among those who either pitched their tents at
the picturesque Lake Moosehead or shot the
rapids that abound in Maine streams.

Registrar Ball gives out the approximate
enrollment of students to date of October 5 as:
Graduates, 206; medical, 202; undergraduates, 190. The total, 598, is somewhat in
excess of the enrollment of last year.
The entering class numbers 69, 6o candidates for the degree of A. B., and 9 special
students. Sixty-three students are entered
in the first year class of the Medical School.
The prospects for the usual up-to-date
Banjo, Mandolin and Glee Clubs, this year,
are very bright. The first trials have been
held and a number of new faces will appear
in the make-up of the clubs. Tours are
planned for both the Christmas and Easter vacations, under the management of Joshua Levering, Jr.,'99. Marion K. Jungbluth,'99, will
this year lead the Glee Club. As last year, the
Mandolin and Banjo Clubs will be led by Girvin Peters.
At the reception tendered the incoming students by the Y. M. C. A., Mr. Eugene Levering, representing the Board of Trustees, spoke
with great feeling of the late Dr. James Carey
Thomas, who for so many years had identified
himself with the Association's work in the University.
Professor Adams will conduct, as a department of the Association's work, a study of the
Apostolic Church and the Growth of Modern
Missions, Saturday mornings at half-past nine.
Professor Adams' course last year on the Lif:
of Christ was largely attended by graduates
and undergraduates, and this year's studies
promise to be equally well attended.
At the conclusion of Prof. Adams's lecture,
Dr. Jeffrey R. Brackett will conduct a half
hour's conference on Applied Sociology, from
o to 10.30 every Saturday.
Dr. Brackett
aims to interest university men in practical
social work, and in the social problems of the
city. The 'Varsity Y. M. C. A. is at present
largely interested in the Lawrence House, a
social settlement work begun in the Winans'
tenements of Southwest Baltimore, in 1893,
by the late Rev. Edward A. Lawrence.
